data.text: Tubeless Tires on Long Distance Cycle Trips?
What are you guys thought about tubeless tires on long distance trips‚Ä¶.

I do, carry plugs, a small tube of sealant, spare tubes and boot kit. Normally small holes seal without you knowing but bigger holes may need a plug or failing that put an inner tube in. Used tubeless on several trips previously and trip starting this weekend
data.author: Sham Belina

data.text: thanks üôè

data.text: I say yes. If it fails on you, you always have the option to use tubes.

data.text: thanks‚Ä¶.that was my thinking to. I was just wondering if people have experience which I didn‚Äôt thought thought

data.text: We used tubeless on our last 2 tours, and belt drives. Each tour was 3000 km off road in the UK. Had no issues at all. Both the tyres and belts did 15000 km before we changed them.

data.author: Trey Freeman
Paul van den Bovenkamp

data.text: Only good experiences so far. I carry plugs and spare tubes just in case but never had to use them so far. Just make sure you can test the tire/sealant combo of your choice beforehand a little. I highly recommend using Stans Race Sealant, well worth the extra money but I also had zero issues riding with Caffelatex.
data.author: True Kunze

data.text: Nope
data.author: James O. Pyke

data.text: Road or MTB trip? I am a tube fan because they can be easier to repair and you can find tubes easier, ie Walmart, ... I don't see the point of going tubeless but caring a tube incase the tubeless tire fails??
data.author: Fred Dixon

data.text: yeah carry a spare inner tube in case‚Ä¶
data.author: Paul van den Bovenkamp

data.text: the point is in the last two years I have 19,000 road miles and no flats that were not my own doing, ie: forgot to refresh the sealant once. While I've watched my friends change out countless tubes. In the last two weeks I've gotten about 10 goatheads and I just kept on riding. One instance I found 5 in my front tire at once.
data.author: Kevin Bilbee

data.text: how often do you top up your sealant Kevin?
data.author: Paul van den Bovenkamp

data.text: About three months or when I'm doing maintenance, I remove the wheels and shake the wheel to see if I can hear any of the sealant bouncing around in there. I also have a small piece of wood I use as a dip stick. I use orange seal endurance, it last longer than the standard. To be successful wiht tubeless I recommend no less than a 28mm tire for road, air volume is your friend. The lower the pressure the better for sealing holes. 100lbs or more of pressure will seal poorly. I run 70 in my 28mm and 60 in my 32mm tubeless tires.
data.author: Kevin Bilbee

data.text: thanks a lot Kevin‚Ä¶.cheers
data.author: Paul van den Bovenkamp

data.text: exactly my approach.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: on my current bike running Vittoria Randonneur Cross, Schwalbe Marathon Mondial, and Schwallbe Marathon XR all with tubes, I have done 60,000km (commuting, country road touring and several outback expeditions including goathead country) with ZERO punctures due to tyre penetrations.

data.text: agree tubes much simpler and cheaper.

data.text: It's a requirement.

data.text: I do not have flats when touring with tubes so why would I change to tubless?
data.author: Joe Trudo

data.text: Got two flats on my first solo trip with tubes. Very nerve racking as I was very secluded and used both my spares. Switched to tubeless after that trip and haven't had a flat since. Tubeless > Tubed
data.author: David Schug

data.text: I like my patch kit and a spare tube. Easy, common everywhere.

data.text: Worth experimenting with removing tyre at roadside if you‚Äôre carrying tubes. I‚Äôve found it extremely hard with 650b tubeless

data.text: Heavy, I like the advantage of a inflated tire for the softer ride.

data.text: 100%
data.author: Mark Holland
Tyler Nusbaum

data.text: Tubeless all the way. If you get a puncture that can't be fixed by the sealant or with a plug you can still put a tube in. Just make sure the tyres aren't GP5000 tubeless, which in my admittedly limited experience are a real ü§¨ to put on- save your thumbs ,
data.author: Richard Goodman

data.text: Unprintable.
data.author: Chris Juden

data.text: Tubeless for any type of riding‚Ä¶ why go to the hassle of tubes?
data.author: Norm Douglas

data.text: Some random thoughts not already covered: In theory CO2 might react chemically with the sealant (it lowers the pH) causing it to cure into solid latex; so I avoid using canisters, and carry a hand pump. Petrol stations/gas stations have air, so I suppose it would be possible to re seat a tyre that way, with a presta to Schrader adapter. Although you would still need to get to the petrol station. You can probably get away with lower pressure than you expect. 12 psi or so with 58mm tyres for example; rolls a bit slower on smooth bitumen but works great on rough tracks.
data.author: Matthew Signorini

data.text: We did a 1000km off road trip on tubeless with no flat tyres. Sand , pea gravel and rock. Was great to not be slowed down by fixing punctures. We were traveling heavy with tent food water etc. loved our tubeless tyres.
data.author: David Thornbury

data.text: Munda Biddi Do you have thoughts on using 32mm wide tyres on that?
data.author: Gary Roberts

data.text: I reckon we would have struggled on the Munda Biddi with 32 mm tyres. You would be fine for a lot of the track but the pea gravel at the northern end and soft sand that we encountered north of Denmark and north of Walpole could be harder. We did the Munda Biddi in November.
data.author: David Thornbury

data.text: Thanks for this. I hope to be doing it in November after cycling from my Sydney home at the beginning of September. *Anyone is welcome to reach out if wanting to cycle Sydney to Perth via the Munda Biddi. I will initially be heading south from Orange to cycle some longer Victorian rail trails.
data.author: Gary Roberts

data.text: Just finished a 3000 km bike packing tour Trek checkpoint SL7 with 40 mm tubeless tyres. No issues
data.author: Sharron Yaxley

data.text: I don't use them. I have tyres that are puncture-resistant. Enough that I have not had a puncture for over 10 years and 60,000km of use on all sorts of rural and urban roads, often loaded with 30-35kg of camping gear.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: very good idea
data.author: Alireza Yasrebdoost

data.text: Have not tried them. Will learn from what is written here.
data.author: Ingo Tophoven

data.text: Tubeless for me.
data.author: Grant Griffin

data.text: My thoughts on long distance cycling is to stick with the things you know you have the best chance of repairing, replacing or finding work arounds when away from major metro areas with access to cycle shops. Think bent or broken valve stem on a tubeless, broken spoke that needs a new spoke nut‚Ä¶ any of those would cause a major issue to someone with a tubeless. I would just be upset that it slowed me down with my Schwalbe marathon plus I ride on. 16,000 miles and one flat.
data.author: Robert Neidlinger

data.text: I'm now on a cross country ride in USA and hadn't have a flat tire so far. 4000km with tube. üòâ
data.author: Uwe W√ºppermann

data.text: .
data.author: Jeff Roe

data.text: I‚Äôll Never go back to tubeless
data.author: Matthew Welsh

data.text: Never had flats with Schwalbe Marathon Mondials and Extremes (OK, I think about 5 in 42,000km) so no need to change. I think the real tubeless benefit comes from the ability to ride at very low pressures with no pinch flats. I rarely run below 30 PSI offroad, so I personally don't have much use for them. I have crossed Arizona and California through the desert on mostly dirt and put sealant in my tubes and had success with no punctures. I think using some kind of sealant is pretty necessary in those areas.
data.author: Tara Weir

data.text: same here. 13000km without a single flat. Modern high quality tires just work fine üôÇ

data.text: Using Hutchinson sector 32mm at the mo. 1000s of miles on and off road - no issues
data.author: Chris Spray

data.text: I bikepack off road with a mountain bike and use tubeless in 27.5 X 2.3 mountain bike tyre, all good. Judging by how many thorns that were in my old tyres, when I removed them to new ones, I'd saved myself a world of painüëç
data.author: Angela Hart

data.text: Although I am an advocate of slime, I don't use tubeless tyres on any of my bikes. Contained in an innertube, slime is a gamechanger.
data.author: Jef Ott

data.text: If you're running narrow road tyres take 2 spare tubes and a tyre fitting tool. I spent over an hour trying to reseat the tyre onto the rim (32mm) without ripping the tube that I'd just put in after a spate of slow punctures. Also I'd recommend a small pump with a pressure guage so you can keep them topped up over the course of your trip.
data.author: Dougie Taylor

data.text: I always try to include at least 1 steel tyre lever. There are times when the extra strength is needed, and there is a knack to getting the tyre on with the lever without pinching your tube. I have busted plastic tyre levers on a couple of occasions, and having just 1 lever left is disconcerting when faced with a tight-fitting tyre.
data.author: Il Padrone
Joan Monterde

data.text: It depends what you call long distance... The longer the distance, the farthest away from developed areas, the more sense it makes to use basic easy-to-fix stuff (ie. inner tubes). Of course, there are exceptions, places with a lot of goat heads would be one. Also, the bigger the tires and the more you are off-road the more it makes sense to go towards tubeless...
data.author: Julien Meissonnier

data.text: It depends on location. Some territory have a lot of plants with spikes or dirty roads with glass, metal wires etc.
data.author: Ilya  Rybakov

data.text: Innertubes everytime for me
data.author: Martin Hendy

data.text: messy

data.text: Always the way to go
